security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-only skill containing pure documentation. No code execution, file access, network calls, or system commands. The markdown file only provides TDD guidance and workflow instructions for AI agents.

content.value_statement: Writing tests after code leads to untested behavior and design problems. This skill provides a strict TDD workflow that drives better code design through the Red-Green-Refactor cycle.
actual_capabilities: Guides the Red-Green-Refactor cycle step by step
Enforces writing failing tests before implementation
Provides test naming conventions and patterns
Includes checklists for TDD workflow validation
Covers common TDD mistakes and how to avoid them
Shows practical examples from simple to complex features
limitations: Does not execute tests or run test frameworks
Does not generate actual test code files
Does not integrate with CI/CD pipelines
Does not provide test coverage analysis

use_cases.title: Learn TDD fundamentals
use_cases.description: Master the Red-Green-Refactor cycle with structured guidance and practical examples.

use_cases.title: Apply strict TDD discipline
use_cases.description: Follow non-negotiable TDD rules to maintain code quality and test coverage.

use_cases.title: Guide AI test-first coding
use_cases.description: Provide clear instructions for AI agents to write tests before implementation code.

prompt_templates.title: Basic TDD setup
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new feature with TDD
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply TDD to implement a new feature. Start by listing all the behaviors the feature needs, then write the simplest failing test first.

prompt_templates.title: Write failing test
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a failing test for the simplest behavior. The test should fail for the right reason. Then write minimal code to pass it.

prompt_templates.title: Expand test coverage
prompt_templates.prompt: Add the next test to force generalization. Write one assertion per test. Stay in the Red-Green-Refactor cycle.

prompt_templates.title: Refactor with confidence
prompt_templates.prompt: Now that all tests pass, refactor the code. Remove duplication, improve names, and extract methods. Keep tests green throughout.

output_examples.input: Apply TDD to implement a URL parser that extracts hostname from URLs
output: Start with a failing test for the simplest case: parsing 'https://example.com' to 'example.com'
Write minimal code to pass: return 'example.com'
Add test for 'https://test.org' to force real implementation
Write implementation: parse the URL and extract hostname property
Now refactor: extract to a dedicated function with proper error handling

best_practices: Write exactly one assertion per test to keep tests focused
Test behavior, not implementation details, to allow refactoring
Take small steps and stay in the Red-Green-Refactor cycle
anti_patterns: Writing tests after production code instead of before
Writing multiple tests at once instead of one at a time
Refactoring while tests are still failing
Testing implementation details instead of behavior

faq.question: What programming languages work with TDD?
faq.answer: TDD is language-agnostic. Works with any language that has a unit testing framework like Jest, Pytest, JUnit, or Go's testing package.

faq.question: How long should the TDD cycle take?
faq.answer: Each Red-Green-Refactor iteration should be short, typically under 5 minutes. If taking longer, the test may be too complex.

faq.question: Does TDD work with AI code generators?
faq.answer: Yes, provide TDD instructions to the AI to ensure it writes tests before implementation code, following the Red-Green-Refactor cycle.

faq.question: Is my test data sent to external services?
faq.answer: No. This skill is prompt-only with no network access. Test data stays local to your AI session.

faq.question: What if tests fail for the wrong reason?
faq.answer: Stop and verify. A test should fail because the feature is not implemented, not due to syntax errors or incorrect assertions.

faq.question: How is TDD different from test-after development?
faq.answer: TDD writes tests first to drive design. Test-after adds tests to existing code, which often leads to testing implementation rather than behavior.
